skills.name: Interpret numbers in a frequency table
Interpret the values in a table of grouped data
Represent data in two way tables
Create a data collection sheet for grouped data

explanations.A: Not quite. We can use this three to identify the row we need to look at but it is not this number that will change. Frequency means how many, adding another child in will increase how many students have 3 pens.
explanations.B: Sally represents another classmate, therefore including Sally will affect the values in the frequency column. Reading across the row from 3 in the 'Number of Pens', we can see that the frequency of 5 will be changed.
explanations.C: I think you have read across from the 3 from the 'Frequency' column rather than the 'Number of Pens'. Remember 'Frequency' means how many, so it will be this that changes when you add in another student.
explanations.D: I think you have read the 3 from the 'Frequency' column, rather than the 'Number of Pens' column. We need to identify where the 3 is in the 'Number of Pens' column and then it will allow us to find the frequency that would change.

explanations.A: I think you have read across from the 3 from the 'Frequency' column rather than the 'Number of Pens'. Remember 'Frequency' means how many, so it will be this that changes when you add in another student.
explanations.B: I think you have read the 3 from the 'Frequency' column, rather than the 'Number of Pens' column. We need to identify where the 3 is in the 'Number of Pens' column and then it will allow us to find the frequency that would change.
explanations.C: Not quite. We can use this three to identify the row we need to look at but it is not this number that will change. Frequency means how many, adding another child in will increase how many students have 3 pens.
explanations.D: Sally represents another classmate, therefore including Sally will affect the values in the frequency column. Reading across the row from 3 in the 'Number of Pens', we can see that the frequency of 2 will be changed.

explanations.A: I think you have looked at 4 in the frequency column rather than the 'number of pens' column. The frequency represents the number of children. Try looking up 4 in the 'Number of pens' column.
explanations.B: In this frequency table, the first column is the 'Number of Pens' and the frequency is representing the number of children. Reading across from 4 pens, we can see that there are 3 children.
explanations.C: I think you have multiplied the number of pens (1) and frequency (4) together to get 4. In this table, the frequency represents the number of children. You need to read across the row from the 'Number of Pens' to find the frequency (number of children) that have that many pens.
explanations.D: Not quite, we do not need to multiply here. We are being asked to find for the number of children who have 4 pens. In this table, the frequency represents the number of children.

explanations.A: Not quite. In this table, the frequency represents the number of children. You need to read across the row from the 'Number of Pens' to find the frequency (number of children) that have that many pens.
explanations.B: Not quite, we do not need to multiply here. We are being asked to find for the number of children who have 4 pens. In this table, the frequency represents the number of children.
explanations.C: I think you have looked at 4 in the frequency column rather than the 'number of pens' column. The frequency represents the number of children. Try looking up 4 in the 'Number of pens' column.
explanations.D: In this frequency table, the first column is the 'Number of Pens' and the frequency is representing the number of children. Reading across from 4 pens, we can see that there are 5 children.

explanations.A: Not quite. This box shows the class interval, the range of heights included in this group. This will not change if you add one more person. Frequency means how many, it will be this that changes if you add people into a particular group.
explanations.B: Not quite, be careful with the inequalities. The class interval relating to this frequency does not include students that have a height of, or are taller than, 140cm.
explanations.C: I think you have selected the class interval that Rebeccas height would fall within, but this just shows the range of heights included in this group. This will not change if you add one more person. Frequency means how many, it will be this that changes if you add people into a particular group.
explanations.D: The frequency column represents the number of classmates whose height falls within each class interval. As Rebecca is 142.7cm, he would cause the frequency for the class interval 140≤h<150 to increase from 5 to 6.

explanations.A: Not quite. This box shows the class interval, the range of heights included in this group. This will not change if you add one more person. Frequency means how many, it will be this that changes if you add people into a particular group.
explanations.B: Not quite, be careful with the inequalities. The class interval relating to this frequency does not include students that have a height of, or are taller than, 130cm.
explanations.C: I think you have selected the class interval that Rebeccas height would fall within, but this just shows the range of heights included in this group. This will not change if you add one more person. Frequency means how many, it will be this that changes if you add people into a particular group.
explanations.D: The frequency column represents the number of classmates whose height falls within each class interval. As Rebecca is 138.9cm, he would cause the frequency for the class interval 130≤h<140 to increase from 9 to 10.

explanations.A: I think you've only counted the tallies in the second group on this row. Make sure you count the first group as well.
explanations.B: I think you have only counted the vertical tallies. Make sure you count the horizontal one as well.
explanations.C: There are 7 tallies in total on this row. 5 in the first group. 2 in the second group.
explanations.D: Not quite. Count the number of marks made in this row.

explanations.A: There are 10 tallies in total on this row. 5 in the first group. 5 in the second group.
explanations.B: Not quite. Count the number of marks made in this row. Each crossed out group represents 5.
explanations.C: I think you have counted the number of crossed out groups. Remember each of these represents 5.
explanations.D: I think you have only counted the vertical tallies. Make sure you count the horizontal ones as well.

explanations.A: Not quite, this is the number of children that like Maths and Guitar. To find Maths and Piano, read across from Maths and down from Piano to find where they would cross over.
explanations.B: To find the value that represents how many children like Maths and Piano, we need to read across the Maths row and down the Piano column to see where they would cross over. This shows us that 7 children like Maths and Piano.
explanations.C: Not quite, this is the number of children that like English and Piano. To find Maths and Piano, read across from Maths and down from Piano to find where they would cross over.
explanations.D: Not quite, this is the number of children that like Maths and Recorder. To find Maths and Piano, read across from Maths and down from Piano to find where they would cross over.

explanations.A: Not quite, this is the number of children that like Maths and Recorder. To find Art and Recorder, read across from Art and down from Recorder to find where they would cross over.
explanations.B: Not quite, this is the number of children that like Art and Piano. To find Art and Recorder, read across from Art and down from Recorder to find where they would cross over.
explanations.C: Not quite, this is the number of children that like Art and Guitar. To find Art and Recorder, read across from Art and down from Recorder to find where they would cross over.
explanations.D: To find the value that represents how many children like Art and Recorder, we need to read across the Art row and down the Recorder column to see where they would cross over. This shows us that 4 children like Art and Recorder.
